pros:
This is an astonishingly nice place to work, in a company experiencing very rapid growth. My recruitment experience was speedy, thorough and allowed me to properly understand the company. In total I spoke with 8 people over the course of a month.
The onboarding is excellent. They bring all new starters across Europe to their EMEA headquarters in Dublin for a day of introductions and to give you your new MacBook Pro and to allow you to meet key colleagues.
The offices are extremely nice, the technology is very good and people work collaboratively within offices and with colleagues around the world.
Most meetings are only 30 minutes, there is a real emphasis on making good decisions using accurate data and then getting on with things.
They have good benefits, including unlimited holiday (to be negotiated with your manager).
And behind it all is a genuine mission to help everyone to find and secure a good job.
cons:
Free snacks in the kitchen have forced me to increase my willpower rather than my waistline!
Inevitably a company growing so quickly can require employees to embrace change and understand ambiguity. This is not for everyone and you have to be willing to accept that today's approach and structures will probably not be around forever.

pros: Weekly happy hours, daily lunches (if you work in Austin anyway), constant communication from top.  Successfully growing company.
cons: Rah-rah culture makes it feel like a cult.  Most employees are very young and immature, picture college.  Work-life balance is awful, this is a 24/7/365 workplace.  Expect to be constantly connected, they love taking advantage of younger employees who don't know any better both in terms of workable hours and pay.  Certain departments are disproportionately compensated but they've corrected this problem with new hires in the last few years creating a huge compensation gap between old & new.  Many older employees are stuck there knowing they can't move on without taking a pay cut.  Once the company was sold off to Recruit, everything went downhill.  Upper management loves to take credit for original founders' successes, rarely take into consideration their own employees.  If you like doing kegstands every thursday, this is the place for you!

pros:
- Awesome culture.
- Good colleagues for the most part.
- Paid lunches, happy hours, etc.
- Dale Carnegie training.
- Opportunity to make pretty good money if you are willing to work.
- Company looks great on your resume and you can turn it into a new higher paying position.
cons:
- HR has no ability to protect employees in the sales arena.
- Lots of micromanagement unless you were lucky enough to get hired by a laid back manager
- Certain roles are harder than others but are paid the same way.
- Management lacks oversight
- Big time favortism
- Open style environment that leads to unprofessional and public lashings by management.
- Business rules lead to some animosity between offices and to many customers being overexposed to Indeed.
- No contracts is great selling point BUT high customer churn rates hurt your wallet and your numbers.
- The product does not always work despite what the kool-aid drinkers might tell you.
- More micromanagement under the guise of "coaching" or training. If you are not a mini-clone of certain managers then you will be shown the door in short order.
- Lack of support and collaboration between sales, finance, and client services.

pros: Work/life balance I guess. I would say nothing at all but there is a 5 word minimum.
cons:
Indeed as a whole is a complete joke.  Working for Indeed was the biggest waste of time. There is NO opportunity for growth and MAJOR lack of communication throughout the company. They preach about being #1 and providing the best opportunity for job seekers and companies looking to fill positions but in reality they do not care one bit about helping others. They will take a business's money and without alerting the business they will take down their ads for absolutely no reason and not reimburse that paying business customer...they just hope that the business doesn't notice. 

Indeed only allows legitimate businesses to post ads through their site and will delete/remove a company from its site if they find out otherwise. Don't get me wrong, this is a great business model and idea theoretically but Indeed does not go about this in the right ways. They do not look into any business they take down in a professional manner and get annoyed if they have to deal with a confused, angry customer wanting answers. 

Long story short, DO NOT WORK HERE IF YOU HAVE ANY MORALS. They have hugely questionable ethics and no morals whatsoever.

review_title: I love so many things about Indeed but it’s changing
pros: So many great people in all sorts of departments. Some game changing products to ensure we continue to help people get jobs.
cons: Promotions non existent but promised continuously. Bringing people in on higher grades of title and salary instead of looking at people already here, who have put in the hard yards. Almost in double figures now of some excellent people leaving in the space of 6/9 months simply because of poor management, lack of promotions, increased salaries and zero strategic planning. It’s such a shame as more are leaving and therefore people left with huge workloads and very little motivation or effort from management to ensure stability at the very least.

pros: Fun atmosphere and great motivation to work
cons: Long hours and tough work life balance

review_title: good company, but inefficient systems engineering org
pros: Indeed has a fantastic work culture. Everyone is smart, friendly, they treat the engineers extremely well, we have great benefits, and it's a joy to come to work. We have big technical projects, but don't have to break our backs to get them done. Compensation is among the highest in the Austin area. I'm proud to work here.
cons: The engineering org is unusually political. If you need a project that introduces new technology, it's not enough to make a good technical case, but I've found you need to appease individuals in the "global infrastructure"/"systems engineering" organization. Without their approval they'll actively block your work; and even with their approval, they'll take months to do the work necessary to let you do your work while imposing unusual access restrictions in the name of cost and security. Almost my entire team is operating at 33% efficiency as we're blocked on systems engineering efforts to move forward. There needs to be some alignment among senior leadership on how we choose to empower developers to occasionally break the mold.

pros:
-Unlimited Snacks
-Great People 
-Great free lunches on Mondays
cons:
I have never been at a company that has experienced such a sudden shift in employee morale. They obviously thought we were making too much money and significantly increased our quotas to the point where less than 5% of reps are going to hit target. I know so many people that are looking elsewhere. I would not recommend working here. The most frustrating part is all we're told from leadership is to stay positive. How can they expect us to stay positive and care when a large percentage of people aren't even going to get a bonus which is the majority of our compensation?

This job was always boring, but we put up with it because of the pay. Now the pay is gone, this is a terrible place to work.

review_title: Was exceptional, now it's just dissapointing
pros:
Unlimited PTO 
Breakfast and Lunch 
Good Health Insurance 
Generally you have a lot of autonomy
cons: Expect to be underpaid here, it's fairly common across most departments. Senior leadership seems to think the free food and unlimited PTO make up for this, but it doesn't. The extreme growth this company has experienced has caused major growing pains. Managers and directors seem more concerned with their own careers and completely unconcerned with how their employees are doing. Favoritism is rampant and noticeable. Hard work is overlooked and people who have less experience are promoted over diligent employees.

job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Austin, TX
pros:
I help people find jobs. 

And I love that mission. I truly believe Indeed is a great company and would recommend it to others.

I'm completely behind the CEO and senior leadership's vision.

I love the product team with which I work. They're wonderful and bright people.
cons:
The marketing org is more political and corporate than those of my past companies. What I mean by that is there is clear downward pressure in the way management instructs which results in a stronger feeling of being micromanaged as a cog than in other tech companies at which I've worked. 

Don't talk to directors directly, and ask your manager to talk to their manager to talk to them. 

Be prepared to get your work reviewed every rung of the way up to the top of marketing only for it to get completely scrapped at the end, wasting months of time in middle management churn.

My manager has been friends with their manager for years before Indeed, introducing an awkward social dynamic where I don't think all the checks and balances are in place for objective discussion.

I do not recommend the product marketing team.

review_title: Good if you are a miilenial
pros: Beautiful offices, good food, excellent health insurance.
cons:
Salaries below market, they ask that people have a master degree and years of experience for a salary in the low 60's ( and that is including bonus) , I wish Indeed spent less on happy hours and a  plethora of activities catered to provide fun to the twenty-something and start paying fairly.  Leadership is provided by people that might have vast knowledge about the company but whose only job has been at Indeed and with poor management skills, tolerance for laziness is ok because preferences towards friends are not unusual, this promotes a culture of self entitlement that makes work harder than it should be. 
Open PTO sounds like a great perk at the beginning but then one realizes that some people overuse it whereas some people use little time off, and for the latest, there is no pay for unused time when leaving.

review_title: No transparency at all and too much harassment
pros: Great perks. Free lunch & snacks, free beer, free gym, game room, overall a very nice office. Open PTO policy makes it easy to have a good work life balance.
cons:
Some people abuse the open PTO policy. I have seen people taking PTO every month and not getting any work done at all, but that is accepted as it's the employee's freedom to decide when and what to work on.

The managers say that it's an open and safe environment, but in reality there is no transparency and no freedom so say what you think. I was told not to point out problems unless I have a solution ready. That is the same as saying "you can't ask questions unless you have the answer." It does not feel like a safe environment when you get criticized for asking questions.

The evaluation system is not very fair, as it gets heavily influenced by the opinion of the managers. Even if the whole team gives you positive feedback, if you don't get along with one manager you will end up with a negative evaluation.

There is a problem with harassment as well. There have been sexual harassment incidents but the company failed to take any action to prevent this kind of problem from happening again. Overall it is not a safe environment to work in, especially if you are a woman.

review_title: Love indeed, the people, the culture, the product.
pros:
Indeed is a fast growing international company, recently opening offices in Germany and Australia. 2 Sales reps asked to move to help build the new offices and got an amazing opportunity to work in new countries. ( I am jealous ) I am based in Dublin. 
 
Another pro is the first week training is in New York/Stamford. Great for your first week to get an introduction into indeed and meet people.
cons:
It is a work hard play hard environment. Indeed has aggressive growth plans and sales are required to make 60 calls a day. ( its not for everyone ) I enjoy the targets and growth and being part of building this company.  It is still a young company which is a + and -. I have great passion for the product which helps me sell and believe in the management team. 
  They also have lots of Sales incentives. Someone just won a trip to Croatia all expenses, I am hoping to win the next one. 
  This is a very fast growing company and if it takes 60 calls a day to hit my target I will make 60!

review_title: No sadder thing in life than wasted talent
pros: Good benefits, free food, no work off hours.
cons: It’s a shame to see the decline in morale and employee quality over the last couple of years. The sales pit used to be full of energy and talent, now it’s full of misery and mediocrity.  Quotas are a joke, products are poorly rolled out and the lack of communication between departments is glaring.  There are far too many undeserving people in management and executive positions who have stifled growth and innovation due to their lack of vision and unwarranted egos.  “Success” has become based on sheer luck, not talent and effort.  Juice is not worth the squeeze for anyone who has aspirations of being fulfilled at work outside of a continually dwindling pay check.

review_title: Growing pains that are getting worse, not better
pros: You work for a growing brand and influence in the staffing and job search space.
cons: There are seemingly no written policies or procedures to explain or inform anything. Managers are not trained to help their teams excel, diversity is put on the back-burner to inclusion (put one pea on a pot of soup and try to make it fit in,... it can't), company is hiring so fast that a decline in revenue will certainly lead to layoffs, HR does not check in with employees, decision making is far too centralized and the company is not actively considering and combating growing competition.

review_title: Great place to work - easy to balance work and life
job_title: Senior Partner Marketing Manager in Austin, TX
pros:
+ Workload is tough, but not crushing. I can work when I want as long as the work gets done.
+ Open PTO. Although experts say open PTO results in fewer days off, it is offered and it's encouraged to take time off to refresh and refocus.
+ People are given time to actually achieve their results. I think it depends on the role, but in my group it is understood that things aren't going to happen overnight. My experience is that management wants people to hit their goals and is supportive of missing goals if you are headed in the right direction and making progress.
cons:
- Fast growth contributes to chaos in that there seem to be a lot of people working on initiatives, but they aren't always aware of what other teams are working on.
- People that have been at Indeed a long time aren't very receptive to pivoting to a more accountable culture - because Indeed was small for a long time, there was often a lack of direct management and direction setting.
- Most teams are geographically dispersed which can make progress on initiatives take longer.

pros:
Indeed is an amazing company to work for!  I have many amazing things to say, but not enough space. I personally feel like my hard work matters here and I am not just another face. I feel like I am a valuable employee contributing to the successes of Indeed.

My team is very collaborative and everyone is here to help one another and learn from one another. It is not a cut throat environment. We all have a purpose at Indeed and that is to help people find jobs!  It is not a place where you are given unrealistic expectations every quarter.  We all care about the same thing and that makes me want to come into work every day and work with some amazing people!  I feel like the quality of my work is valued just as much as the quantity.

I love Indeed and my recruiting team and I cannot see myself working for anyone else!
cons: We are working on improving a lot of things within the recruiting industry like our new ATS and it sometimes slows down some of our work we are doing, but we adapt and make it work.

pros: Snacks, work life balance, labtop
cons: I have worked at indeed for a year and a half. Things were amazing when I first started. I saw a bright future for myself here at indeed to expand on my current skills and to learn new sales, and business skills.  But then…things took a turn at the end of 2018, headed into 2019…. Reps at indeed will no longer hit green BREAKING NEWS! I have create da lifestyle around the pay structure I was used to. That lifestyle is now gone. I find it hard to manage my lifestyle, take care of my family, and take PTO. I had planned on building my career here at indeed and now I feel as if I am “sticking it out”I feel discouraged, and ashamed coming into work everyday. The morale in the office is beyond down, and it is somehow the reps fault? How does upper management except reps to hit targets that do not even mathematically even make sense to hit due to the current spenders, and new spenders coming in. We are being set up for failure. They are better off letting people go, or being transparent in what is going on within the organization so that we CAN be positive and have a better hope for tomorrow.

review_title: Finding people jobs. What a joke if they cannot offer their own people a decent environment to work in.
pros: If there were any (perceived) pros of working for Indeed they quickly were forgotten about after I was stabbed in the back by my very inexperienced TL.
cons: Backstabbing a go go. Very low retention rate of holding on to good people. No careers at Indeed. Only jobs if you can take the BS and unrealistic workload and targets. They are not so cool to work as they claim to be. Indefinite number of holidays a BIG joke. If you want to take two or three weeks off in a row managers refuses. The whole aim of all those free breakfast, sport drinks, snacks and meals is to keep employee in the office as long as possible.

pros: Snacks and occasional lunch and breakfast
cons: Hated how management played favorites

pros: Good people, environment , Diversified to a point.
cons: Call centre environment almost like a cult, only one thing matters in there and that is the sales number . At one point asked to work from home while out sick with a cert. There are more meetings than make sense and to look busy management will sit in with you on a phone call - that's all they do just so it seems that they are busy and justify their roles. Never asked are you ok it just what a are your numbers for next week. Its a boys world in there and only friends or friends of will progress, not one female director in AB or AA. No structure in how a week would look just what is your sales number as it needs to be brought to senior management .

review_title: Great company and environment to work in, some growing pains
pros:
- 100-140k OTE for SAE, 
- challenging environment with room for significant personal and professional development
- I work as an senior account exec within the growth segment of the business. I see passionate management team handling a period of rapid growth as well as possible. 
- pension
- the usual office perks etc..
- possible to take 30+ days off if u get ahead of your number
cons:
- growing pains all over the place but accepting these are going to be there with a positive mentality towards helping yourself, your team mates and your clients grow will stand you in good stead
- the inevitably poorly set up accounts that come up from acquisition every quarter add to our effective growth rate. Hold these accounts and their churn in escrow for one quarter
- confusion over new products that seem to be rolled out before they are ready

pros: Indeed is a fun place to work.  I find all of the negative reviews about sales at Indeed surprising - I been here almost been here two years and everyone I work with seems to like it.  I get to work with fun people and sell a good product. Love my coworkers, the happy hours, my standing desk, the free meals, and overall fun office environment/day to day.  I make more money than the majority of my friends. Some of the comments in the other reviews are almost entertaining - my advice to you unhappy indeeders is to spend less time filling out unnecessarily long reviews online and more time doing your job.    You might be surprised to find out that sales is actually fun when you are good at it.
cons: Nothing significant enough about to write here.   No job or company is perfect but I can honestly say I plan on staying at indeed as long as they will have me.

review_title: A great time to work for Indeed...
job_title: National Account Manager in London, England
pros:
Great to work with a product that 'just works' for clients when using a combination of the huge amount of free of charge services along with the strategic paid-for products.
A well-known brand globally, and by far the market leader in my region - the  UK
Very nice Central London office.
Energetic and driven team.
Good culture (team nights out, helpful colleagues), great onboarding (Dublin for entry to mid level, and New York for Senior level due to the location of the training talent for the senior onboarding sales programme).
Great perks including unlimited holiday (subject to management approval of course!), Private dental and healthcare, snacks, drinks, catered lunch on Wednesdays, catered brekkie on Fridays, and Happy Hour from 4pm Friday (food, chat and drinks), Apple laptop and more...
Fair pay and good bonus and commission structure.
Disruptive, flexible product, and cost effective for the client.
Continually evolving and growing product range.
Internal opportunities due to arise as headcount will continue to grow over next 1-2 years
Not micro managed
cons: Some back end internal systems need some updating, which will happen...

review_title: Great! if you're a not an employee of an emerging market
pros: Indeed has a wonderful culture and work environment, great benefits, a good level of communication from the board
cons:
No matter how good you are, how many good feedbacks you receive and your development in your role, you will be stuck at the same role level for years with no perspective of growing if you are located in a emerging market. 

It's sad to see your efforts worth almost nothing and people from others markets changing positions much faster with much less expertise than you (specially when you are asked to teach/help them when they supposedly should know more than you)

review_title: Just another number at Indeed AU
pros:
Unlimited PTO
Catered breakfasts, lunches and happy hour 
Fully stocked refrigerator 
Healthcare
cons:
Very little career progression- their is nowhere to move unless you’re in the Sales, Marketing, HR or Client Success function. I was working in Sales and found it demotivating to know that I would never progress further in my career based on my discretionary efforts, in working my accounts. 

The focus was always on hitting your targets and management never cared how you went about it, just that you did it. 

Zero support from senior management including the HR function. 

US centric company.

Management are YES men.

pros: Good Product, Free Food that is actually Good.
cons: Poor management, little support, poor pay, high turnover.  Indeed likes to tout themselves as equals to the other desirable companies out there, when they come nowhere near the same caliber as the big dogs in the industry (like Google or Facebook).  There are some very smart people at Indeed, but they have an elitist attitude that is not necessary or warranted.  They don't listen to employees when ideas are presented or suggestions are made to improve things.  I have felt many in management are flat out rude and unprofessional in the way they communicate with others (or the fact that they don't follow up or communicate).  The recruiters I worked with talked a big game, but it was very deceptive.  People are brought in with a lot of potential and talent, only to be thrown to the wind and ignored.  I have been routinely disappointed in seeing talented people walk out the door, almost at a constant rate.  The turnover is horrid.  And while the benefits are good, the pay is not competitive at all.

pros: Catered meal, ping pong table, and happy hour here and there. Easy product to sell if you have good leads. If your leads are good and you aren't too lazy you can easily hit your quota. Base salary sucks but if you aim for mid size companies you'll receive a good return on commission.
cons:
This is a "Sip The Koolaid" culture. To succeed here just sip the Indeed koolaid, brown nose your manager and pretend to be bestfriends with all of your coworkers.

I've heard management use inappropriate language, talk insanely bad about employees who quit or were fired. They would go on linkedin profiles and make fun of previous employees. 

Some managers are good and others aren't. However, if you catch on quickly and don't need a lot of guidance than the bad managers won't impact you so much.

Benefits aren't good. The medical benefits didn't offer much coverage.

job_title: Senior Account Executive in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: I met some lifelong friends and mentors.
cons: Indeed is a great place to start your sales career and gain experience in inside sales. But even when you've proven yourself to be a top sales rep, there is no room for growth or promotions. Senior leadership does not promote qualified reps, nor do they promote woman into senior leadership. The way they set up quotas, you'd think they are wanting to see you fail so they don't have to pay you a big bonus. There is no transparency. Indeed is going downhill, and needs to rethink the way they run a sales floor and organization. They are not competitive in the market with pay, and now not even with culture. Don't be fooled by the game rooms, or fully stocked kitchens. At the end of the day that stuff doesn't matter, and what matters is how leadership is treating you. And leadership here does not give two sh*ts about you. Your just another person in the seat making the calls!

pros:
Benefits - I think this is the one big thing why so many people have stuck to Indeed since they first began. 
Free food - all the time , breakfast, lunch, snacks
Open PTO
Balanced life (unless you are unlucky to get a lazy lead/ manager who would play politics to keep himself safe)
Work from Home
relaxed environment
Diversity
Great Happy hours
Lots of freebies and tees
Engineering teams might be better not sure though.
cons:
Products are not really planned and implemented well.
Every  person who needs to prove himself starts a new product/ application leading to redundancy, confusion
Lack of a well defined process
Lack of documentation
Most of teams are new and have been in existence since 2015 mid. Hence have all the problems a new process would face and so would the team members.

job_title: Client Support Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: Great culture, great people. All the usual perks that come with a trendy tech-based company such as weekly happy hours, team events, catered meals etc. Really awesome product - you get to speak with clients day over day that confirm our mission statement: we help people get jobs.
cons: For the amount of work a Client Support Specialist takes on, they should be much more fairly compensated. We are a large part in making sure accounts run smoothly, campaigns are set up correctly, and upsells are happening for key accounts. However, we do not get paid any portion of commission for this work. In addition, we are also charged with ramping up our very new sales team and getting them up-to-speed on internal and external products, without being fairly compensated for the effort.

pros:
Medical and dental insurance
Breakfast everyday
Lunch on Wednesday
Happy Hours on Fridays
cons:
They are changing the structure of the company and basically eliminating what was attractive about Indeed.
- Now you need to work 3 more times to earn the same money
- They have cut the bonus 
- With targets that are not done according the market (3 to 4 times more) you are not able to make quota and reach Senior level career progression
- Conditions are not the same for new people so people who was here between 2 years to 9 months were able to do quotas very easily and with the changes the new people can´t do it... at least not as fast as before
- Have bumped with people doing xenophobic comments and also racist ones

pros: I've been working at Indeed for close to a year and its one of the best jobs I've had. Some of the reasons why its so good, ongoing training and support to help you succeed in the sales role. Fun place to work, lots of external events and activities planned. Stocked pantry, catered lunches and breakfast as well as Friday Happy Hour. Work life balance, supportive and encouraging environment.
cons:
Diversity is lacking, there are hardly any Aussies working here. 

There are a few negative people in the sales team which can make it slightly frustrating at times coming into the office however the majority of the team is very focused and driven to succeed, so try to stay away from the negative ones. A good thing is that a lot of the negative people are slowly leaving.

pros: Benefits are great however they are just a ploy to lure good sales talent in the door. Barely anyone availed of the "unlimited PTO" as sales targets were ridiculously high and there was huge pressure to achieve them each quarter.
cons:
Call centre environment. A minimum of 40-50 cold calls per day. 
Micromanagement. 
Glorified call centre 
Cult like feel to the culture. Everyone is given Indeed merchandise to wear, there is constant updates on social media of this perceived "fun" life inside indeed, however the true reality, in my experience, was that most people on the sales floor were really unhappy due to the pressure and stress of the role.

job_title: Senior Account Executive in New York, NY
pros:
The sponsored jobs product is truely the best product out there for employers seeking an active flow of candidates.

Your selling an industry leading product.
cons:
Failed innovation. Company’s “new products” are all falling flat. Since 2014 indeed has launched 4 “big” new products to keep us competitive, and keep innovating this hr space. 

None of these have become profitable, rollouts have been sloppy and not on time, canabalize revenue (and relationships) with existing client base. 

Plus, upper management is now micromanaging middle management, which in turn  leads to middlemangment having to micromanage top performing reps who go 110% on the year and bring in millions for the company.

review_title: There's a reason all the high performers are leaving now
job_title: Client Success Specialist in Toronto, ON
pros:
- free snacks
- unlimited paid time off
- open concept office
- decent benefits (except for therapy, which you'll need a lot more of if you're working here)
cons:
- cliquey management team that uses high school politics to intimidate high-performing employees while advancing those who don't threaten the status quo
- little to no communication between internal teams, especially with regards to product updates and process changes (clients are often the first to know)
- no actual growth opportunities (all hiring and promotions are indefinitely on hold amid company restructuring)
- involvement in employee resource groups not considered "working time"
- you must log your washroom breaks if you are taking mainline calls

review_title: Good company, stuck in old ways
pros:
Well known global brand
Free breakfast
Lower level employees are fun and friendly
Constantly trying to grow with the changing landscape
cons:
Tries to be an everyman so the products get rolled out without proof of concept and sales people are forced to sell something that doesn't work for the customers
Lots of nepotism in order to progress and it's still very bro-focused on the sales floor
HR is terrible, they aren't trained compliantly and don't give credence to real employee concerns
Workload is not distributed properly
There is literally no trust - managers will sweep the floor looking for people not at their desks, and chastise employees for taking breaks or using personal call booths (why are they there then?)
Painfully start-uppy for how established they are

review_title: Innovation Labs - Full Stack Software Engineer
job_title: Full Stack Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Innovation Lab's is like the Bell Labs or Skunk Works of Indeed. We have the freedom to explore new ideas, funneling creativity into real live tested products. Indeed's prides itself in being extremely data driven and investing in employee growth. Innovation Lab's takes Indeed's core strengths further with moonshot projects. The mission of these moonshots is to grow Indeed's impact, validate the feasibility of these ideas, and leverage Indeed's assets along the way. I feel like I'm able to make a big impact and my contributions are appreciated. This group would be ideal for strong Django/full stack/start-up minded engineers and developers.
cons: The free breakfast and lunches are extremely healthy. Quinoa, flaxseed, kale, raspberries, etc. These options are great, but sometimes.. you just want a slice of pizza.

pros: 1. Company culture, 2. Benefits, 3. Flexibility, 4. Smart and creative workmates (which tells a lot about Indeed notoriously being VERY picky in hiring), 5. Relatively-young people to work with, 6. Data-driven decision-making, 7. Senior management's effort to make everyone feels great working here.
cons: 1. Could have been better pay for the amount of work we're responsible for, 2. Treat your non-engineer employees equally. Don't make us feel like second-class citizens, 3. Watch out for middle-managers and their office politics.

review_title: Mixed Feelings- Seattle Office vs. Austin Office
pros:
-Free lunches and snacks
-Open PTO
-Bi-monthly happy hours
-Casual dress code
-Awesome Seattle employees 
-Supportive site leadership
-Fun "start-up" culture in Seattle

I would give the Seattle Indeed Office 4 stars
cons:
Very big disparity between Austin and Seattle offices and Engineering and HR orgs. The Indeed Engineering org has quarterly evaluation periods for employees of all levels. The Indeed HR org doesn't do quarterly evaluations for any of their employees below the senior leadership level. 

-Most Talent Attraction managers sit in Austin and have very little visibility into Seattle employees performance
-Micro-management 
-No career path for roles in Talent Attraction (recruiting) 
-Unclear expectations and quarterly evaluation metrics
-Unclear pathway to conversion for contract employees 
-No confidential method to provide feedback to HR/TA leadership 
-Lack of women in leadership roles

pros: Free food, transportation options, decent benefits, parties galore
cons: Toxic environment, defensive HR and Employee Brand Program Managers who rather than acknowledge and empathise with unhappy employees, they write defensive screeds where they deny all wrong doing. I have never worked at a more racist, sexist, and company. I literally needed months of therapy to rebuild myself esteem. My manager displayed  a narcissistic tendencies and life was very difficult around this person. No one helped me and HR made it sound like I was the problem. This person broke so many rules, did and said so many inappropriate things. I went to their manager, he did nothing, I went to HR & was also stone walled there. So I left. Stay away from this toxic employer unless you are young, white and male. or a thin white young blond woman. Everyone else will have massive difficulties. Indeed is a reflection of the worst in our society. Absolute rock bottom.

review_title: Great company - Dreadful Managers in UK/IE
job_title: Senior Account Executive in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Indeed it's SLT had an amazing and humbling response to Covid 19.
Lay offs as a last resort.
Guarantee % of bonus, even if under performed as the market is struggling.
Quata adjustment for Q1 as market shifted.
The message has consistently been, help out where you can, plan for recovery, keep safe.
cons: So I have been at Indeed over 2 years now, and have had there has always been an issue with management, however what is particularly frustrating is that in the ACQ org, the message being put out there is seemingly the exact opposite of the SLT, pushing  for hard close, chase your tagrget above everything else, and if you underperform you're a free loader because you're garaunteed your bonus.

pros: Great perks. Great people.  Social events.
cons:
Lack of methodology in trying to achieve aggressive sales targets. Being ambitious is healthy, however if reps (especially new reps) aren't given the necessary skills and knowledge from the top down in how to try and achieve these targets, everybody loses. This is evident in the quantitive sales performance vs targets for reps across the board. Asking for extra help actually shoots you in the foot because it will be used as ammunition later down the track. A lot of irony in the sense of being micromanaged about some aspects such as KPIs for it to later be abolished due to the realisation of its ineffectiveness.  Also, there was sometimes a feeling of inconsistent metrics that reps were judged upon - nothing was ever good enough!

How can reps have confidence in management if management doesn't have confidence in them!

pros: I took this job after people told me not to as they mentioned bad reviews on glassdoor. They warned me not to take the job and i was scared to be honest. I have been proven wrong. It is the most amazing company to work for. They really look after their employees from the very start. Amazing training , great environment, fun team, good product, easy to sell, good location, good pay, you get commission and bonus, gym on site, free food on Wednesday, great benefits with healthcare and more. I feel so at home. I used to work at google where the environment is amazing but indeed is so much better as there is no politics. They are moving the office ti the docs in 2019 and more benefits will be available then. Indeed all the way!
cons: i have nothing to be honest..

pros: Snacks, catered lunch, unlimited pto
cons: Where to begin... this place is an extension of college it’s a sad that they pride themselves on transparency when actually nothing is transparent. People are walking on eggshells constantly in fear of losing their job for performance. This sales is not “you get what you make of it” some people have good books with solid accounts where others get awful accounts and no opportunities to actually do well. Management is a joke they promote people who performed well instead of people who are good leaders

review_title: Incredibly well looked after even in these unprecedented times
pros:
Constantly putting employees, clients and general public ahead of gains.

A great way of assessing a companies core values is not how they treat people during the good times, but how they go above and beyond to look after it’s employees during the worst times.
The fact that Indeed were one of the first to make the move to WFH for all employees during the early days of Covid19 speaks volumes. Making an effort to retain all current staff making sure that if a role becomes dormant IE. Talent attraction that can move to another part of the business. Open and honest Q&As with CEO and other SLTs where they are incredibly vulnerable and open and really show that they are also people with family and friends the same as us all. Truly fantastic bunch of people and make working at Indeed a privilege
cons: Honestly besides the actual job itself being tough, there are no cons.

pros: I have worked for several small and large companies in multiple states and Indeed is the best company I have ever worked for by far!  I currently work in the Austin location and we have free breakfast and lunch Monday through Friday.  We also have a barista making coffees and smoothies all day.  This office also has a gym / fitness center will classes offered.  Leadership puts on a monthly meeting that allows the President and department leaders to give an update on the company and were we are headed.  Co-workers are friendly and eager to help train and share knowledge with each other.  The company culture and environment is fun yet professional.  People at Indeed care about doing a great job and support the overall mission of helping people get jobs.  They also offers happy hours, game nights and holiday events monthly.
cons: Only would suggest that the three Austin offices get combined for everyone to have the same company experience.

pros:
The pay can be fantastic
Great sales training for someone who has not been in sales before
Some fantastic people
Office perks, free food, office aesthetic is great
cons:
Wild favoritism, favored reps are consistently pushed over their quota threshold through backdated revenue. These reps are also given better leads consistently. It’s something that was noticed by even sales team leads and has never been addressed
New products are poor. 
Sales strategy is as simple as “let’s add headcount and try to sustain 100% YOY growth. No market analysis, no real strategy. Headcount and that’s it.
Zero transparency with regards to sales targets that are constantly changing. Pay structure is also constantly changing 
Some great managers, others who have advanced simply because of tenure and luck
Your book and your managers opinion of you can have incredible impact on your success, both good and bad. If you’re in a tough vertical with a bad manager...good luck

review_title: The truth lies somewhere in the middle
job_title: Account Executive in San Mateo, CA
pros:
The reviews on here are very skewed, most bad ones are by disgruntled employees who couldn't hack it, and most good ones are ones that management asked interns to write (you can tell by the generic and contrived language).  Here is an unbiased review of Indeed:

I worked at Indeed for about 2 1/2 years in the San Mateo office and recently decided to leave when my maternity leave was up (probably outing myself here).  I left not because I was unhappy, quite the opposite.  But I crunched the numbers of what I would be making coming back and having to build business again verses what I would need to support my new family, and it just didn't add up.  I also felt stuck professionally since I had stopped believing that I would ever be able to move up at Indeed, no matter how well I did (and I did pretty well).  I would have gladly taken on more responsibility if they had given me the chance.

  Most of the bad reviews on here I would have agreed with a year ago, BUT management has made a big effort to improve employee morale once they found out how unhappy a lot of people were. Outings and team building events are big here and I think management tries to nip most morale issues in the bud before they get bad.

A big Pro here is that they do hire fantastic people to work with.  My former team especially seemed to gel, and I loved coming to work mostly because I enjoyed being around them.   My direct manager had a knack for hiring awesome people, and he was also honest with me about what I needed to improve on and what I did well.  I also credit the senior manager for really turning the San Mateo office around, he made it his personal mission to whip the office into shape and I think he succeeded.  

Another Pro is that Indeed does have a great product that works.  It's something that you can feel good about selling because it has value to HR professionals and most that try it are happy they did.

Most people leave Indeed at the year mark, but if you stick it out, you can easily become proficient at your job and learn to work smarter.  You don't have to "biz rule" people and can instead rely on referrals and upsells for most of your quota attainment.

All in all, this is NOT a bad job.  It's sales, so at times it can be cutthroat and stressful, but what sales job is easy?  Rely not just on your manager but feel free to ask your team for help, most team members take pride in helping one another be successful.
cons:
No room for advancement and can be a little frat house-y.  If you are out of college, you will make enough so you can support yourself, but if you have a family, you won't make enough unless you move up, which is extremely difficult.  There is a reason why lots of new parents have to leave Indeed, which is pretty sad.
The 60 call a day rule is good for newbies that are starting out, but senior reps who sell bigger deals should focus on longer conversations, less calls.  This is the only company I have ever worked for that has a "one size fits all" approach to how they manage new and senior people.
Do not work here if you have a stick up your a**.  There is no HR in the San Mateo office for a reason, half of the people there would be fired multiple times over for violations, and I'm including myself here. When I say violations, nobody does anything horrible, but be prepared to hear crazy things come out of people mouths sometimes.

review_title: Quality of Life and a Flat Org
job_title: Talent Acquisition Worker Bee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Many organizations talk about QOL and being a flat organization. Indeed truly lives those ideals. I was always treated as an adult not a cog in machine. I was given what I needed to accomplish my work and was never micromanaged. This was sometimes challenging as I was in a satellite office and not the HQ, but it was still a great perk. Talking of Perks, the SF office is competitive with the best our city has to offer--- and the Austin office outshines many of the places I have been in SF. The quality of everyone I worked with, from the top down was beyond compare. There are some very smart people in all the offices I visited. Finally, the commitment to Data Driven work, in all work areas is unparalleled with any other place I have been, including Wall Street Fortune 500s
cons: Growing pains, growing pains, growing pains. Trying something over and over because it worked before--- and not realizing things have changed.

review_title: Sales got harder. Commission was decreased then cancelled.
job_title: Senior Account Executive in Stamford, CT
pros: I started in sales in 2014, got promoted after a year. The first 12 months or so were great, they paid really good commissions. Was easy to get first promotion that came with a nice raise. 40 hour work week. Don't ever have to come in early or stay late. CEO seems very bright and has a nice plan for the company. Benefits are solid and relatively inexpensive for employees. Free food, snacks, drinks, happy hours. Stamford is also a really cool office.
cons: Zero lead generation. You will find all of your own leads. Structure of sales teams changed, became impossible to find leads, but quotas got higher, commission and bonuses were unreachable for many reps. Company started offering other services, which were sold by different teams, and the different teams called on the same opportunities, often causing competition for a sale. Being micromanaged is a part of the life (how many calls, how many minutes those calls were, what times you should be making calls, how many emails, ratio of calls to demos). 60 call per day minimum regardless of what you have scheduled for the day. Managers send emails in all capital letters when the team doesn't hit goals. Recently completely changed the compensation structure. Took monthly commission out and replaced it with quarterly performance bonus. Stamford office isn't very diverse, they hire alot from a particular college in Connecticut that leads to a lot of bro-culture. Unlimited paid time off sounds cool but you'll hear "not good to take time off in the beginning/middle/end of the quarter".

pros: This place is a dream for anyone coming straight from college looking for a decent entry level wage, good benefits and lots of office hook ups and drama.
cons: If you are even a mid level professional, this won't be the place for you. In my year plus there, there was an alarming lack of transparency throughout the organization. Up front, I was told that the salary I took which was a step back, would be guaranteed with a 20% bonus. This wasn't the case so it ended up being just a true step backwards financially for me. I also was never told I had to travel and was asked to travel often. The best way to describe the culture is being the new kid walking into the cafeteria senior year. It is very clicky and gossipy, and no matter how hard you work, are transparent on your end and ask the same, it will never be returned. You will instead be rewarded for brown nosing, etc...

review_title: A great company to work for!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Mateo, CA
pros:
- work/life balance is unbeatable

review_title: Flexible, fun place to work and grow
pros:
Indeed is a creative company focused on the singular mission of helping people get jobs. This makes the work very rewarding as you know that you are trying to solve problems that will impact someone else's life significantly. 

Given the broad nature of the company and the many teams working within Indeed, you can spend a lot of time trying to track down information related to what other teams are doing.

Management at Indeed is very open to new ideas and is constantly experimenting with ways to improve the Jobseeker experience. This can be good and bad; you need to be ready for new products to roll out on a regular basis, but there is also the opportunity to have your ideas become the next new experiment at Indeed.
cons: It can be difficult to find the information that you need from other teams

pros: Comp plan is great, unlimited potential. The environment is pretty easy-going, not you typical sales pit. The office is very relaxed, dress is casual and a full stocked kitchen. It's about as good as it get its aside from the Facebook and Google offices. The product is the best in its industry no doubt. You are given inbound leads and almost everyone knows Indeed's name, so selling isn't that difficult.
cons: Leadership is slightly lacking, none of the managers or directors were hired from within Indeed and are all brand new. The people are great, but there's not a whole lot of energy and uniqueness to the business. Everyone kind of just does there own thing, granted most everyone is pretty friendly and willing to help out.

review_title: Great people, good product, okay leadership.
pros: Young group of people that work hard and play hard.  Most are friends that hang out after work and on weekends.  Feeling of being part of growing something.  Product overall is good, very innovative, works well.
cons: Short-sighted management, with strict call and activity metrics on salespeople.  They take a robotic approach to selling, very scripted, very methodical... and don't allow sales people to be creative or 'go out of the box' to sell and win deals.  People will make calls, just to make their call quota for the day/week... for fear of being put on a performance plan.

pros:
Great Offices/Culture
Amazing Perks/benefits( Unlimited PTO, matching 401k, heath screening, wellness plans, catered Lunch and Breakfast) 
Great Commission/bonus structure.  Most of my friends that have been here over a year are easily clearing 6 figures.
Strong Management Focused on Growing the business. 
Training - Lots of Training  
Tons of Upside/ Career Paths.  If you perform well opportunities will be there.  
#1 in the World! 
Innovative.
We Help People Get Jobs
cons: Pressure to grow a Company.   But Sales or any Job has pressure involved.  Expectations are high on us.   But We have the means to reach them.  If you are not cut out for a Competitive Fun environment, where you will be pushed to be your best, this is not for you.

review_title: Mission focused company that takes care of its employees
job_title: National Account Executive in Stamford, CT
pros:
Mission focus is terrific.  Everyone knows the goal is to get people jobs and decisions are always made with this objective in mind.  It also gives a great sense of belonging and appreciation for what you role is in that mission.  

As any high margin internet/software business, they take care of their employees.  Well designed office space, competitive comps, nice office perks (I've worked at Google too and they are very similar).  

High growth, strong product and smart people making decisions.
cons: Growing pains.  At an early stage company things change fast (territories get redivided and commission structure changes were two things that impact the sales organization) and you have to be willing to change focus as the needs of the business change.

review_title: Great employee, huge focus on employee experience and welfare
pros:
Well paid, plenty of opportunities for career progression, training and development.

Realistic targets given to sales org and Acq after pandemic, supportive management from directors and TLs focusing on employee development and positive reinforcement during unprecedented time for the business. 

Great benefits, healthcare, food, events, and many resources available to all employees.

Excellent Senior Leadership, particularly demonstrated during Covid-19 with a policy to ensuring all employees are looked after, and prioritising their health and safety.

Tight knit teams, friendly and welcoming atmosphere. Huge supports available to those who are struggling if requested.
cons:
Heavy focus on Indeed brand can feel a little artificial, but this can be engaged with or not as desired.

This is the only criticism I could think of, I would highly recommend this company to anybody.

review_title: Great place that could be improved
pros:
- Customer-focused company: if you don't understand why are you doing something, it's either you're doing something completely wrong (and better to raise it up immediately), or you just don't know something (and better to learn in ASAP)
- Almost no communications barriers: you could directly approach anybody, directly go and even edit almost any information source and codebase - and that would be very much welcomed
- Processes in the company are a great help and not the obstacle to almost anything you'll want to do be it some personal stuff or some initiative
- Unlimited PTO was a great thing for me for personal things - I'm guilty to borderline abuse it:)
- Truly international company with huge amount of people from US, China (including new grads), Japan (including new grads), and literally countries all across the globe (Brazil, Israel, Spain, Singapore to name a few)
- Data-based everything from evaluation presentations to product decisions to interviews
cons:
- Tokyo office steadily becomes an execution office with all the interesting/impactful work steadily been moved to US
- I'd suggest to avoid Japanese managers: even if they're great people in person, I'm not aware of a single case when they didn't brought Japanese-style management under guise: shift responsibility, blame your team, micromanage, boss around etc. That doesn't apply to non-Japanese managers who are majority.
- Advise: impact matters above everything else. Management don't communicate it clearly, so expect to adjust first quarter or two. Optimise for maximum impact with minimal effort, push back everything else.

review_title: Indeed is an embarrassment to other silicon valley companies
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: Great teammates, however that is the only pro to working at Indeed.
cons: If you want to stay stagnant in your career, get treated like a child, be absurdly micro-managed, make around $30k less than other Silicon Valley counterparts, then you should work at Indeed. They do not care about their employees at all.  When looking at successful silicon valley companies, they all have a few things in common.  They treat their employees like they actually are valued; Indeed does not do that.  They also encourage growth and potential in their employees; Indeed does not do that.  Other silicon valley companies will actually pay you a decent salary, and have managers who communicate with you transparently instead of giving you vague or no answers or guidance.

review_title: If you want to be beyond micromanaged, this is the place for you
pros: Pay structure is pretty good, although flooding the sales floor with inexperienced children makes it harder and harder to hit quotas
cons: Go find an Indeed Sales Director job posting.  Requires 7+ years sales experience and 3+ years management experience.  There is not a single director in the CT office with anywhere close to that.  Directors treat sales people Iike children and, even though they have never done the job themselves, talk as though it is simple.  Zero motivation.  Even the top sales people hate the place.

pros: The culture at the company is amazing!  Benefits for the employees include unlimited PTO, free breakfast/lunch, happy hours, company summer and holiday parties, a holiday gift (luggage!), volunteer opportunities,  IRGs, and a great work-life balance.  They also provide monthly communication from the executives to ensure all employees are kept up to date on initiatives and plans.  The company offices are also really well done providing a best in class work space for every worker type.
cons: There is some lack of accountability in engineering/product because of the philosophy to allow people to work at their own pace and be creative.  Although this may be a workplace benefit for those employees, it can be a point of frustration for others who are waiting on their work to be accomplished.

review_title: Best company I've ever worked for
pros:

A wide range of alcohol at happy hour, or any other occasion.
Great opportunity to further your career.
People here are simply sound.
Never an issue while taking time off.

Healthcare

review_title: Tossed aside with no mentoring less than a year after being hired
pros: Stellar health plan, great perks as a remote employee (snacks delivered quarterly, start-up money to set up home office), even more perks at Austin (free breakfast, lunch, coffee bar, too much to list). Pay and bonuses are outstanding. Many great people working there.
cons:
I was subjected to the dreaded Performance Improvement Plan (PIP) after just 7 months at the company, then was let go a month later. Quarterly reviews are nice to gauge your standing, but I never realized how quickly you could be cut loose if you don't meet expectations in your first 2 quarters.

How did that happen so fast? Because my team was all about fast: speed was their primary focus; I was expected to code fast, and I simply wasn't fast enough. (Never mind the fact that I delivered almost zero bugs while I was there...) I never got an explanation as to WHY speed was so important, either. There were no deadlines, no imminent sales demos, nothing I could see that would demand such speed. As far as I could tell, it was all about being fast for fast's sake; in other words, bragging rights.

What was most upsetting was that I was a remote employee, and I had no direct management guidance or mentoring during my tenure. I was just expected to know how to do everything, and if I didn't know, learn quickly. I wasn't quick enough.

The atmosphere felt very unsafe. I didn't feel like I could fail, because the failures would simply be recorded and used against me in the next review. I didn't feel like I could ask for help because it would just highlight that I wasn't up to par with their standards. I was very much on my own, and for a remote employee, this is death; there is no chance for success.

I honestly question the monetary decision of investing so much money in hiring a software engineer only to let them go less than a year later, especially without any mentoring. Even after my managers realized I didn't know as much as they thought I did, they didn't see any reason to grow me into the role. When you make billions of dollars a year, I guess you can do that.

My advice to future Indeed software engineers: know your stuff before you sign on with Indeed. You won't last long if you think they'll help you ramp up.

job_title: Senior Account Executive in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Unlimited holidays, free food / snacks, great company culture and friendly staff. Multiple other perks such as company discounts at certain shops, gyms and restaurants
cons: Some growing pains in terms of communication between departments. Your enjoyment of your job will be influenced in large part by the department you work in, the variety or repetitiveness in your day to day role and your manager.

review_title: Be prepared for a seesaw of experience
pros: When it’s good, it’s good. The food. The swag. The office. Everyone is really approachable and engaged. You have somewhat of a work/life balance.
cons: Then it goes down. Your merit increase is a joke.  You are being paid below market, and trying to argue your case is useless. You can’t park at the office. You have mandatory work from home days because they’ve hired too many people and have no place to put them. Managers miss 1:1s and career advancement is minimal. You can take only so much lip service about how valuable you are, how they have big plans, etc. Then you leave, because your manager’s telling you are worth more, and then, they treat you like scorched earth. Not great.

job_title: Senior Account Executive in Stamford, CT
pros: Compensation and company culture aka happy hours, lunches, breakfast, snacks
cons:
Middle management is filled with directors who don't know the product as well as most senior reps and do not do anything except micro manage and preach more more more instead of being offering solutions.  Directors do not grow the people on their team they just shove more metrics down their throats and think thats going to get the company where it needs to be.  Metrics do not close deals, smart selling does and this company does not understand that and simply treat sales like a glorified call center.  

We moved to a much better PTO system yet if you are in sales you are questioned for any and every day requested no matter if its two weeks in advance or two months.  I'm pretty sure that is illegal.  Where is HR?

review_title: A great place to work ... but bureaucracy is starting to creep in
job_title: Data Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Indeed grew massively over the course of 2016 and essentially has complete market share over the job search market. It's a stable company in a stable industry with a solid, laid back culture and an energetic, youthful workforce.
cons: The company is growing too quickly and, with the massive scaling, a lot of bureaucracy is creeping in. Some of the startup "perks" are there ... but the startup "feel" no longer is. This is a place where you can work comfortably and without stress; however, it's no longer a place that encourages active experimentation. It's stable, in both the best and worst use of the word.

pros:

-Free food and beverages at most locations

-MacBook Pro
-On-site gym 
-Beautiful office locations 
-Training in CT is a great experience
cons:

review_title: Understand what you getting into - honest review
job_title: Senior Account Executive in New York, NY
pros:
- Great entry level sales training
- The potential to make a great salary for work that is not complex
- Free Snacks, Drinks, Lunches  
- Rapid progression from Account Executive, to Senior Account Executive if you hit your numbers 
- Company likes to promote from within and gives employees the ability to move around
- Indeed is a great product that works well for Advertisers 
- Product is relatively simple to sell
- Management is patient with reps who may not be performing well and offer assistance
cons:
- Management is obsessed with metrics TO A FAULT. The reps are required to hit 60 dials and/or 150 minutes of talk time. This seems achievable however there a many obstacles that make this very difficult i.e customers emailing with account questions, conversations with client services, internal meetings, team meetings, account research for meaningful conversations, documenting in the CRM everything you have done, etc. 

What is the result? Most reps fill their numbers by making fake dials, sending generic emails, calling phone numbers that they know will never be answered.  Further this results in a sales process that is more laborious, transactional, and ineffective. Reps who have to endure through this soon get burned out, or are really good at gaming the system. 

Open PTO as mentioned in my "Pro's" is not really OPEN PTO. It is just a marketing gimmick used to attract candidates. Any PTO you would like to take off needs to get approved. If you are not pacing to hit your quota you will not get approved because you are behind, not doing well, etc. If you are performing well, pacing to hit quota you can still get denied PTO for various obtuse reasons. It is not really "Unlimited PTO".

job_title: Account Executive in San Mateo, CA
pros: Amazing product that is useful to both employers and job seekers. Fun culture and perks including happy hours, team building events, lunches, and contests. There's a ping pong table in the break room that helps break up the monotony of the inside sales routine.
cons: No lead generation and inexperienced management. Many of the directors in the office have been promoted from within and don't really know how to lead, which has led to high AE turnover recently. There's one director who really knows what he's doing and has a strong squad, but that seems to be the exception rather than the norm. Every AE is expected to make 60 calls/day which is often unrealistic.

review_title: A continuation of "Frustrating. No room for growth in certain departments. Vast favoritism and growth disparity"
pros:
-Free Food
-Happy Hours
-Good Benefits
-Overall Indeed culture
cons: The previous post about Search Quality could not be more accurate. Since the previous post made back in March, aside from a team meeting, nothing has changed. Favoritism is still very predominant on some of the sub-teams. The only constant in this team is the frequent Org changes. The pay is low and there  is absolutely no value for existing employees. While you may have been an employee for 2+ years, without warning, you may be put on probation. Newer employees are paid higher and are given more value. Overall, it is still an disappointment with no chances of any improvement any time soon. The Search Quality team tarnishes Indeed as a company.

review_title: Excellent place to work & great learning every day

pros: Indeed is a great place to work if you love being in a sales capacity. You can make a lot of money fairly quickly. The other roles seem to be compensated fairly as well.
cons: Most of the people here are very young, FRESH out of college. This leads to the culture being very frat-ish. Also, managers are always stressed and tend to take it out on the people they lead. If something comes down the pipe from senior management be prepared to take some heat. You will also be expected to perform at the same level as more senior people on your team which can be very frustrating.

pros:
Real work life balance:  I do not do any overtime like in my previous job and I do not bring my laptop home which is great. The company is really interested in the well being of their employees by organizing wellness challenges (charity run, sport activities..)
I have been working at Indeed now for a few months but I really feel part of a team and a company as a whole. I received a welcome box when I started, good training and a lot of swags.  There are already 2 international travels lined up for me next quarter. My horizons are broader and I really believe that I will be able to grow quickly. Personal development is part of our daily routine as the company is growing fast. Ambitious, professional and determined candidates are welcome here.
cons: Not at the moment, to be honest.

pros:
Indeed is by far the best company I've ever worked for. They are continuously taking steps to improve the organization and routinely asks employees for feedback. There are new initiatives being rolled out almost on a weekly basis from big things like Diversity/Inclusion to small like making a custom "Indeed" coffee grind. In fact, my office has one of the more diverse leadership teams I've seen at any company I've worked for. 

Last thing I'll say is that it's hard to find a company that has a better mission than indeeds, especially when your company's motto is "We Help People Get Jobs".

- great benefits
- unlimited PTO
cons: Nothing real to report here. Every growing company is going to have some pains but in the grand scheme of things - we have it pretty good.

review_title: Politics seeps throughout the engineering organization
pros:

Data-driven culture
Ability to drive initiatives and iterations

You're a one man/woman army- Prepare to find your own leads (approximately 1.5hr /1 lead), manage your leads or they get taken (business rule), cc to schedule appointments (60 dials/day min.), prepare for presentations, present, prepare proposals, follow up, contact your current clients, manage all your current clients, manage  check their page placement, maintain cpc, track spending for all clients, help with their ats, and manage their tech issues.  

Never ending cold calling 
Minimal support 
Poor compensation

Backwards sales structure 
Complicated CRM
No job security 
Revolving door

Extremely low employee retention 

Do yourself a favor and apply somewhere else.

review_title: Graduates Beware: Terrible Place to Start
job_title: Account Executive in New York, NY
pros: Nothing besides free snacks and drinks.

1) Management does not give a damn about you. You either meet the call quotas or get yelled/threatened at like your garbage. All you are is a paid employee that they use as a human cold-caller to advertise their job search functions.

review_title: Good company perks but new CS leadership is a joke
job_title: Client Success Manager in New York, NY
pros: Flexible hours, good product, great teammates. People are genuinely passionate about helping people get jobs. Fitness classes offered. Catered food multiple times per week. My Director is on top of everything and I love my Senior Director too!
cons: New CS leadership is an embarrassment to anyone with any sort of intelligence. pros:
Lunch, Medibank, happy hours.  
I'd recommend working here, as long as you're not in the sales team.
cons:
I absolutely loved indeed it was the best job for years, unfortunately Indeed made a poor decision jumping to a sales model built for established markets within a very new market. 
My salary and earning potential was cut in half after the change and there was nothing left for me. 
International HR suggested we should have spoken to HR before leaving to voice concerns, I had three separate meetings with HR regarding a particular issue however absolutely nothing was done. The HR team is incompetent. 
Upper management is delusional, and managers and sales reps are left to suffer their poor choices.

pros: Indeed is a lot of things. Coming out of college, it was a perfect place to start. Everything about Indeed attracts recent grads - “unlimited “ PTO, happy hours, lax dress codes and plenty of socializing. It has incredible training and they do invest a lot in their new employees. They have snacks at all times, Friday has beer at wrap up, etc. I wouldn’t change this being my first job for the world.
cons:
That being said, the real problem comes after 1 - 1.5 years of employment. The shininess of Indeed and all it’s perks goes away, and you see that it is a bandaid solution to keep their employees happy. Indeed has become a churn and burn type of place. Senior management has NO idea how bad the morale on the ground is. Most of the sales job (especially with a closed book in growth) is complete luck. I know amazing reps who had no chance of hitting due to their books and people who are new hires pacing to 150%. These discrepancies are very well known, but nothing is ever done about it. If your book is trash, youre just screwed.

Management is THE DEFINITION of micromanagement. Managers don’t care about how much you close, they care about the KPI’s they need to report up to their bosses. If you ask for help or say a problem, there is no solution other than to make more dials. That “unlimited” PTO is a wash for sales. You will be guilted any time you need to take time off, whether it is for sickness, vacation, or safety. Last snow storm, everyone got sent home BUT sales. Sales was pressured to stay by their directors, and it took all of us HOURS to get home and many got in car accidents.

My biggest issue in general is career pathing. There is NO clear career pathing and an absurd lack of opportunity to move up. You become a Senior Account Manager based on quota attainment, but then there is nothing - and forget about any forward movement if you aren’t a straight white male in the direct employer segment. In Stamford, there is not ONE female director or team lead in the DE-ACQ segment. In DE-growth, there is not ONE team lead that is not a straight white male. Out of 14 teams, there are TWO female directors who came from Account Management. This is 100% an old boys club so good luck moving up if you aren’t an aggressive man with a wolf of wall street attitude in which you want to work your team to the bone. 

Look, it’s not all bad. I met amazing people. My personal bosses were incredible people who respected me and coached me to become the sales person I am today. I made lifelong friends. The training was amazing! But in the long run, it is not worth the consistent stress and obvious favoritism. In the end, all you are as a sales person is a replaceable cog in a corporate machine. 

To all the Sales people working there - don't drink the koolaid. You WILL make more money outside of Indeed. It is NOT the best opportunity you have. And honestly, after the reorg, the money wasn't that good anyway unless you blew it out in ACQ.

review_title: Fantastic place to work for only those who work hard

job_title: Account Executive in New York, NY
